captions.text:
Why are gas stations always built
right next to other gas stations?

Why can I drive for a mile
without finding a coffee shop

and then stumble
across three on the same corner?

Why do grocery stores,
auto repair shops and restaurants
always seem to exist in groups

instead of being spread evenly
throughout a community?
While there are several factors

that might go into deciding
where to place your business,

clusters of similar companies can
be explained by a very simple story

called Hotelling's Model
of Spatial Competition.

Imagine that you sell
ice cream at the beach.

Your beach is one mile long
and you have no competition.

Where would you place your cart
in order to sell the most product?
In the middle.

The one-half-mile walk may
be too far for some people
at each end of the beach,

but your cart serves
as many people as possible.
One day you show up at work

just as your cousin Teddy
is arriving at the beach
with his own ice cream cart.
In fact, he's selling

exactly the same type
of ice cream as you are.

You agree that you will split
the beach in half.

In order to ensure that customers
don't have to walk too far

you set up your cart a quarter mile
south of the beach center,
right in the middle of your territory.

Teddy sets up a quarter mile
north of the center,
in the middle of Teddy territory.

With this agreement, everyone south
of you buys ice cream from you.

Everyone north of Teddy buys from him,
and the 50% of beachgoers in between
walk to the closest cart.

No one walks
more than a quarter of a mile,

and both vendors sell
to half of the beachgoers.

Game theorists consider
this a socially optimal solution.

It minimizes the maximum number
of steps any visitor must take
in order to reach an ice cream cart.
The next day, when you arrive at work,

Teddy has set up his cart
in the middle of the beach.

You return to your location
a quarter mile south of center

and get the 25% of customers
to the south of you.

Teddy still gets all of the customers
north in Teddy territory,

but now you split the 25% of people
in between the two carts.

Day three of the ice cream wars,
you get to the beach early,

and set up right in the center
of Teddy territory,

assuming you'll serve
the 75% of beachgoers to your south,

leaving your cousin to sell
to the 25% of customers to the north.

When Teddy arrives,
he sets up just south of you
stealing all of the southerly customers,

and leaving you with a small group
of people to the north.

Not to be outdone, you move 10 paces
south of Teddy to regain your customers.

When you take a mid-day break,
Teddy shuffles 10 paces south of you,

and again, steals back all the customers
to the far end of the beach.
Throughout the course of the day,

both of you continue
to periodically move south
towards the bulk of the ice cream buyers,

until both of you eventually end up
at the center of the beach,

back to back, each serving 50%
of the ice-cream-hungry beachgoers.

At this point, you
and your competitive cousin

have reached what game theorists
call a Nash Equilibrium -

the point where neither of you
can improve your position
by deviating from your current strategy.
Your original strategy,

where you were each a quarter mile
from the middle of the beach,

didn't last, because it wasn't
a Nash Equilibrium.

Either of you could move your cart
towards the other to sell more ice cream.

With both of you now
in the center of the beach,

you can't reposition your cart
closer to your furthest customers

without making your current
customers worse off.

However, you no longer have
a socially optimal solution,
since customers at either end of the beach

have to walk further than necessary
to get a sweet treat.
Think about all the fast food chains,

clothing boutiques,
or mobile phone kiosks at the mall.
Customers may be better served

by distributing services
throughout a community,

but this leaves businesses vulnerable
to aggressive competition.

In the real world, customers come
from more than one direction,

and businesses are free to compete
with marketing strategies,

by differentiating their product line,
and with price cuts,
but at the heart of their strategy,

companies like to keep their competition
as close as possible.

title: Why do competitors open their stores next to one another? - Jac de Haan

comments.author: Charles Yazzie

comments.text:
Actually, it has a lot more to do with zoning restrictions.  Most people 
think there is one kind of commercial zoning, where there are many types of 
commercial zoning.  The type of commercial zoning for any given property 
determines the type of businesses that can be on that specific piece of 
property.  The limitations of the zoning, combined with the needs of the 
community determine what is the best business for that property - and often 
the type of biz that could flourish in that specific location limits it to 
just two or three different biz's.  That is how you end up with the same 
types of biz's in the same location.﻿

comments.text:
In the real world, you cannot move your store every other day so this 
example is foolish. Sometimes competitors are close and sometimes are not 
close to each other. When they are close it is usually because that area is 
known as the "industry X district" so consumers/Johns go to that area 
knowing that they will have many choices of furniture stores/chinese 
restaurants or prostitutes. That targeted consumer traffic attracts more 
businesses that offer the same wares. That is the explanation and it is 
much more mundane than what this video suggests.﻿

comments.author: AirplaneRandy

comments.text:
The beach example is horrible.  Everyone at the beach is so diverse, it's 
an almost exact average of wealth and race.  Poor mixed with rich mixed 
with average salary Joe.  The north end of the beach and the south end of 
the beach would draw equal business to each cart when they are splitting 
50/50.  Bring this theory to a real town or city, and the north end may be 
poor and/or the slums, the south end may be the wealthy...therefore the 
north end cart will never make money and will have to move into the south 
end territory.  For the most part, businesses are set up strategically in 
town/cities to make the most money, depending on what it is they are 
selling and to whom.  Gas stations are set up in certain places due to 
regulations and areas of land they are only allowed to build on (so this 
scenario doesn't even matter), banks now are set up in certain areas (for 
reasons other than this scenario), cafes and the style of those cafes are 
set up in the areas that serve those "types" of people.﻿

comments.author: mraccident

comments.text:
+Vincent Verheijen P.S. - this whole example should try to show the most 
plausible scenario. Instead - everything here is least plausible:
   They are cousins instead of enemies.
   The have carts; so they can move them everyday; and they slowly come 
together. When in reality - people keep their business in one place from 
the beginning.
  They are on a one dimensional surface essentially; where the approach to 
them is only from two sides.

This is the mechanism of denial\rationalization in work.
comments.author: mraccident

comments.text:
+Vincent Verheijen Assumption is the mother of all mistakes.
If you put a point in the middle of a two dimensional area - it can be 
approached from all sides. There are no favorite sides.
The important problem with the logic of this video - is that they try to 
answer the question "Why do competitors open their stores next to one 
another?".
This is not the reason why they do it.
I can easily think of a better hypothesis.
In the beginning of a settlement - some businesses are needed. A few 
different ones are established. The first people open where they see that 
there are already stores etc. The next ones do the same. The first ones may 
be different businesses; but eventually - someone who only knows the trade 
he knows - comes alone. Where will he open his business? Of course in the 
commercial center; where all the people come to spend money; especially if 
people know that there are several similar businesses for a similar purpose 
in the same place.
This is a reason. In the video - there are no logical reasons to the 
question proposed.
Very likely that it's the makers of the video - who misunderstood Game 
Theory.

comments.author: Michael Barber

comments.text:
Legally, a corporation's primary obligation is to maximize the value of its 
outstanding shares. Socially optimal solutions are (almost) never the most 
profitable decision. Many are saying things such as, "businesses are driven 
to operate in a business centre because that's where the consumers are". 
How do you think the business centre came to exist? The Nash Equilibrium is 
definitely a factor - but not the absolute answer.

Let's take off the blinders for a minute: the Nash Equilibrium is just a 
drop of water in the massive bucket we call economics. This video 
illustrates, as simply as possible, this phenomenon and intentionally 
ignores other factors that would obviously impact the two businesses. What 
if Ted was just a nicer guy than Ed? Many would go to Ted's cart over Ed's 
without hesitation over something as simple as that. But that isn't 
relevant to this theory or video, and doesn't make the Nash Equilibrium 
"wrong". It just means it's an influence rather than an absolute, decisive 
factor.

Is this simulation perfectly realistic? No, but that doesn't mean that the 
Nash Equilibrium isn't applicable to business analytics. Just like the 
thousands of other business theories that exist, this theory isn't a 
boulder that stands alone but rather a brick in a larger construction than 
itself.﻿

comments.author: schackmountain

comments.text:
This is a nice illustration of game theory, but I don't think it's the real 
explanation for the phenomenon described. A new, lesser known coffee shop 
will probably want to position itself near a well established rival to 
steel some of its customers rather than hide itself away in some other part 
of town and rely on advertising to make itself known.

Additionally, some towns will have one area that is clearly optimal, so 
it's natural that businesses will cluster there.﻿

comments.author: Siddharth Jindal

comments.text:
Sometimes a Nash equilibrium IS a socially optimal solution. Take car 
dealerships - the average person buys a car only once every several years, 
so the convenience of having all the dealers clustered together outweighs 
the hassle of getting to "dealership row" far more than it would with a 
regular errand like a supermarket or an impulse-buy product like fast food.﻿

comments.author: MortallicA91

comments.text:
I'm not going to pay more for the same good just because a store is "local 
" who cares. Also a more complex model accounts for the carrying capacity 
of population centers. A "local " store will exist where a small population 
can support the business. This is why there are many locale restaurants but 
very few local specialty watch shops. The watch shop must draw on a whole 
metropolitan area to stay afloat and therefore locates at a center of a 
large city. Don't be so quick to denigrate consumers or producers, this is 
one of the few areas where the economic equilibrium is not optimum but 
looked at more broadly the stores will locate in a way that most 
efficiently distributes land.
